caption: US Sen. Tom Cotton Sitting on a Pile of Gold

result.explanation: The provided entities are completely unrelated to the news caption.  The caption mentions US Senator Tom Cotton and gold, while the entities refer to military units (Airborne Brigade) and locations (Kirkuk, Iraq). There is no overlap or connection between the caption's subject matter and the extracted entities.

candidates.title: Is This US Sen. Tom Cotton Sitting on a Pile of Gold?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows U.S. Sen. Tom Cotton of Arkansas sitting on a pile of gold during his time in the military.
In June 2020, an old photograph supposedly showing U.S. Sen. Tom Cotton of Arkansas sitting on a bed of gold bars during his time in the military recirculated on social media.
This photograph, displayed above, appears to be real. However, it does not feature Cotton.
This picture was reportedly taken in May 2003 and shows a member of the 173rd Airborne Brigade after nearly 1,000 gold bars were confiscated from a truck in Kirkuk, Iraq.
CNN reported at the time:
For the second time in a week, U.S. troops have discovered what appears to be a cache of gold bars hidden in a truck, which could be worth just less than a quarter of a billion dollars, according to a Pentagon official.
Soldiers from the 173rd Airborne Brigade discovered 999 gold bars hidden in a truck during a routine traffic inspection near the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk within the last two days, Pentagon officials said.
We have been unable to find a definitive and credible source for this picture, but it does match up with news reports from the time. The patch on the person's arm, for instance, appears to match the winged sword patch of the 173rd Airborne Brigade:
Also, because this picture was taken in 2003, Cotton can be ruled out because the senator didn't join the military until 2005. Cotton also served with the 101st Airborne Division (whose patch resembles the division's nickname of "Screaming Eagles"), not the 173rd Airborne.
When we reached out to Cotton, a spokesperson told us: "The man in the photo is not Senator Cotton."
candidates.description: The photograph appears to be real, but the caption tells a different story.

result.explanation: The news caption "US Sen. Tom Cotton Sitting on a Pile of Gold" is inaccurate and misleading. Snopes.com fact-check debunks the claim. The image shows a soldier from the 173rd Airborne Brigade in Iraq in 2003, not Senator Cotton, who joined the military in 2005 and served in a different unit.  Snopes confirms that Senator Cotton's spokesperson denied the image depicted him.
result.supporting_points: Source 1 (Snopes): "This photograph, displayed above, appears to be real. However, it does not feature Cotton...This picture was reportedly taken in May 2003...Cotton can be ruled out because the senator didn't join the military until 2005...When we reached out to Cotton, a spokesperson told us: 'The man in the photo is not Senator Cotton.'"

final_result.explanation: The image shows a soldier from the 173rd Airborne Brigade in Iraq in 2003, not Senator Tom Cotton.  Senator Cotton joined the military in 2005 and served in a different unit. Snopes.com fact-check confirms that Senator Cotton's spokesperson denied the image depicted him. The internal check finds no relation between the image and the provided entities, supporting the external findings. The visual evidence and external fact-checking strongly contradict the caption.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks confirm that the caption is inaccurate. The image depicts a different soldier in Iraq in 2003, not Senator Tom Cotton, who joined the military later and served in a different unit.
